In this paper, NH3-SCR catalysts were prepared by impregnating transition metal Mn loaded on SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 and adding sulphuric acid to further improve the denitrification performance of the catalysts. The optimum performance of the catalysts was explored by varying the loading ratio of Mn and the concentration of sulphuric acid. XRD, Raman, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, XPS and In situ DRIFTS were used to characterise the changes in the surface properties of the catalyst after loading with Mn and to investigate the reaction mechanism. The results show that the denitrification performance of the catalyst was improved after the loading of Mn and sulphuric acid treatment, and the temperature window became wider, with the denitrification rate consistently remaining above 80% at 200∼400 °C and the denitrification activity reaching 92.6% at 250 °C. Suitable Mn and sulphuric acid content allow for greater Mn-Ce interactions, resulting in better dispersion of active substances such as Mn oxides, MnSO4 and MnSO3, which can provide more adsorption and active sites and increase the reaction rate. The Mn atoms replace some of the Ce atoms in the CeO2 lattice, increasing the mobility of oxygen and thus improving the low-temperature activity of the catalyst. In situ IR results show that the catalyst follows both the Eley-Rideal mechanism and the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism at 250 °C. The acidic sites on the surface are abundant and the Lewis acidic sites are the main active sites on the catalyst surface. Both mechanisms work together to facilitate the denitrification reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mn-loaded Sulphation NH3-SCR Denitrification mechanism Data Availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) are one of the major air pollution problems and are extremely harmful to the ecological environment and human health. Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) using NH3 as the reducing agent is currently the preferred method of treating NOx in coal-fired power plants worldwide. The core of the technology is the preparation of the catalyst. Currently, commercial flue gas denitrification catalysts are mainly V2O5-WO3-MoO3/TiO2, but there are many disadvantages in the use of this catalyst, such as high denitrification activity window, high production cost, the toxicity of active ingredients, and easy to cause secondary pollution, so it is necessary to develop a new catalyst that is economically efficient and environmentally friendly. In recent years, research on catalysts has focused on both the active component and carrier performance. Compared with conventional carriers such as CePO4 and TiO2, SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 has inherently good catalytic properties, a wide temperature window and good resistance to sulfur and water, without causing adverse effects on the environment [1]. It has the potential to be a carrier with excellent properties. It was found that the transition metal Mn is a multivalent element that can form several stable oxides and the interconversion between ions facilitates the redox performance of the catalyst. Cheng Liu [2] loaded MOx (M=Cu, Mn, Co) onto CePO4 carriers by hydrothermal and impregnation methods, and the results showed that the denitrification activity of the MnOx/CePO4 catalyst was the highest, and the modification of MnOx greatly improved the low-temperature SCR activity, which still reached more than 80% at 180 °C. In addition, the MOx/CePO4 catalyst also showed good water resistance and N2 selectivity. Xiaojiang Yao [3] prepared a series of MnOx/CeO2 catalysts by adjusting the solvents (deionized water, anhydrous ethanol, acetic acid, oxalic acid solution) to improve the performance of low-temperature NH3-SCR, and the results showed that the MnOx/CeO2 catalysts prepared with the oxalic acid solution as the solvent had the best catalytic performance in the range of 100∼250 °C, with The NO conversion was over 80% and the low-temperature sulphur and water resistance was good, which may be attributed to the enhanced electronic interaction between MnOx and CeO2 by the solvent oxalic acid, which improved the oxygen vacancies in the carrier CeO2, resulting in improved denitrification performance. Runduo Zhang [4] prepared LaMnO3, LaMnO3/TiO2 and LaMnO3/CeO2 catalysts and investigated the effect of the carriers on the low-temperature catalytic performance of NH3-SCR. The study showed that the best low-temperature catalytic performance was achieved with CeO2 as the carrier, mainly because the interaction between LaMnO3 and CeO2 was conducive to the movement of lattice oxygen when the temperature was less than 200 °C, which could promote the partial oxidation of NO to NO2 and make the NO reduction reaction proceed according to the fast NH3-SCR reaction, thus significantly improving its low-temperature catalytic performance. In this paper, medium and low temperature denitrification catalysts were prepared by loading Mn onto SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4. The effect of Mn element and sulphuric acid on the denitrification performance of the catalyst NH3-SCR was investigated, and the catalytic reaction pathway and denitrification mechanism were studied. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Experimental materials The names of the chemical reagents used in this experiment are cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O), sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3), sodium fluoride (NaF), phosphoric acid (H3PO4), 98% sulfuric acid (H2SO4) and manganese nitrate (Mn(NO3)2), all of which are analytically pure and purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. The gases used in this experiment were ammonia (NH3) and nitric oxide (NO) from Xuzhou Special Gas Factory, oxygen (O2) and nitrogen (N2) from Baotou Fuhua Gas Co. 2.2 Preparation of the catalyst Different masses of manganese nitrate were placed in 20 ml of water and stirred until dissolved. 2 g of SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 sample [1] was added to the solution, sonicated for 2 h, dried in a drying oven at 80 °C and roasted at 500 °C for 2 h to obtain Mn(0%, 5%, 8%, 10%, 12%, 15%)/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst samples in different ratios of Mn to the carrier. The above-derived optimum loading of Mn in Mn nitrate was placed in 20 ml of water and stirred until dissolved. 2 g of samples after acid leaching with different sulphuric acid amounts (0, 0.6, 1 mol/L) were added to the solution, sonicated for 2 h, dried in a drying oven at 80 °C and roasted at 500 °C for 2 h to obtain samples of Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalysts with different sulphuric acid modification amounts. 2.3 Evaluation of the activity of the catalyst The experimental apparatus for activity testing is mainly composed of a precision gas mixing chamber-flow metre, quartz tube, riser furnace, sampler, Fourier infrared spectroscopy flue gas analyser and computer data acquisition system, the experimental setup is shown in Fig. 1 . First determine whether the gas line is well sealed, carry out a constant gas flow test in the empty tube so that the gas flow in the gas line is constant at room temperature and the gas content detected is constant for the flue gas analyser (GASMET DX4000, calibrated from ppm level to percentage content level with an analytical accuracy of ±3% of the corresponding calibration range). Quartz wool and samples were then added for temperature rise testing, the temperature point was set to rise 50 °C/5 min and the denitrification performance of the catalyst was tested in the range of 100∼550 °C. The constant temperature at the checkpoint was 30 min and the gas content measured was the volumetric concentration of NO, NO2, N2O, NH3 and O2. The simulated gas components are as follows: 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 3 vol% O2 and N2 as equilibrium gas with a total gas flow of 100 mL/min and a volumetric air velocity of 10,000h−1. The denitrification efficiency (NOx conversion) and N2 selectivity of the catalysts are calculated by Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. (1) C R NO x = ( NO x ) in − ( NO x ) out ( NO x ) in × 100 % (2) S N 2 = ( 1 − 2 ( N 2 O ) out ( NO x ) in + ( NH 3 ) in − ( NO x ) out − ( NH 3 ) out ) × 100 % Where (NOx)in, (NH3)in are the volumetric concentrations of NOx and NH3 detected at the inlet of the flue gas simulation system after smoothing, ppm; (NOx)out, (NH3)out, (N2O)out are the volumetric concentrations of NO, NH3 and N2O detected by the flue gas analyser at the outlet of the flue gas simulation system detection, ppm. 2.4 Catalyst characterization and equipment The characterisation and equipment used in this paper are as follows: The denitration performance of the catalyst was analysed using a Fourier infrared flue gas analyser from GASMET (DX4000, Finland). Physical phase analysis of the catalyst using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD) (PERSEE XD-3, China). Raman spectroscopy of the catalysts, using a DXR type spectrometer from Thermo Fisher. Analysis of the acid intensity and qualitative analysis of the acid amount of the catalyst, using a PCA-1200 multifunctional chemisorbed (NH3-TPD, H2-TPR) (Beijing). Analysis of elemental valence on the catalyst surface, using an EDX1800E instrument (XPS) from Tianrui Instruments Ltd. In situ IR sorption experiments using a VERTEX Model 70 Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (DRIFTS) (Bruker, Germany) (including an MCT detector and a high-temperature micro-infrared accessory). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD To study the phase structure changes on the catalyst surfaces with different Mn loadings, XRD analysis was carried out, as shown in Fig. 2 (a). MnO2 diffraction peaks appear at 2θ=43° and 61°, but the peak shapes are small, which is attributed to the fact that Mn enters the surface of the carrier in the form of ions, and is converted into Mn oxide after high-temperature calcination, so the dispersion is better [5]. The diffraction peaks of MnSO4 and MnSO3 species can also be detected from XRD. Studies have shown that metal sulfates have very excellent catalytic performance. Compared with metal oxides, denitration catalysts with metal sulfates as active components have higher denitration activity and a wider temperature window [6,7], which may be one of the reasons for the enhanced activity after Mn loading. After loading Mn, the peak of CeO2 shifts, and the half-peak width broadens, and the broadening is most obvious when the loading is 12%, indicating that Mn and Ce interact after loading Mn, and the interaction is larger when the loading is 12%, which is beneficial to The SCR reaction proceeds. After loading the active material Mn, XRD analysis was carried out on the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalysts with different amounts of sulfuric acid, as shown in Fig. 2(b). It is found that after acidification of H2SO4, the diffraction peaks of MnSO4 and MnSO3 species can be detected from XRD. The catalyst with metal sulfate as the active component has higher denitration activity and a wider temperature window. At the same time, the diffraction peak of Mn3O4 appears, but with the increase of H2SO4 content, the diffraction peaks of the active species (CePO4, CeO2 and Ce7O12) on the catalyst surface were enhanced, which inhibited the catalytic activity. It shows that when the amount of H2SO4 is too large, the crystallinity of the main active substance will increase and its activity will be inhibited. 3.2 Raman spectroscopy To gain an in-depth understanding of the structural composition of the catalyst after loading Mn, the Raman test was carried out on the catalyst, as shown in Fig. 3 . When Mn is not loaded, a sharp Raman peak of CeO2 appears near 461 cm−1 [8], and there is a Raman peak near 1020 cm−1, which belongs to the Ce-O vibration peak of CePO4 [2]. After loading Mn, the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst showed CeO2 Raman peaks between 428∼439 cm−1. Compared with the Raman shifts without Mn loading, the peak intensities became weaker. This may be because Mn atoms are doped into the lattice of CeO2, resulting in the deformation of the CeO2 lattice. To reduce the distortion, the Raman shift moves to the direction of low wavenumber. On the other hand, the lattice substitution can also cause the splitting of the active vibrational modes of F2g. The oxygen vacancies caused by the substitution of low-valent cations Mn3+ and the shrinkage of the unit cell caused by the doping of the smaller radius ions Mn3+ (0.065 nm [9]) will both promote the shift of the characteristic peaks of the F2g fluorite structure of CeO2 to lower wavenumbers [10]. When the addition amount of Mn was 12%, the distance of this characteristic peak shifted to the low wavenumber was the largest, indicating that its interaction with CeO2 was the strongest and the oxygen mobility was the largest. According to Spanier [11], the increase of the unit cell constant can be used to explain the phenomenon of Raman shift moving to low wavenumber. The previous XRD analysis shows that the diffraction peaks of CeO2 are broadened, indicating that the reduction of catalyst particle size increases the unit cell constant, which is consistent with the movement of Ce-O bonds to low wavenumbers. The above analysis shows that Mn atoms replace some Ce atoms in the CeO2 lattice, which increases the mobility of oxygen, thereby improving the low-temperature activity of the catalyst. 3.3 NH3-TPD To investigate the number of acid centres and the variation in acid strength of the catalysts with different Mn loadings, the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalysts were experimentally investigated for NH3-TPD, as shown in Fig. 4 (a). Peaks less than 200 °C are attributed to desorption peaks resulting from the adsorption of NH3 and NH3 on weakly acidic sites physically adsorbed on the sample surface. The peaks from 200∼400 °C are attributed to the desorption peaks arising from the desorption of medium to strong acidic sites. Peaks greater than 400 °C are attributed to desorption peaks arising from the desorption of strongly acidic sites. As can be seen from the graph, the Mn loading of 10% produced a desorption peak at the weakly acidic site and two peaks at the strongly acidic site. The three peaks produced at 12% Mn loading were attributed to peaks in the weakly acidic site, peaks in the moderately strong acidic site and peaks in the strong acidic site. The Mn loading of 15% did not produce a desorption peak from the adsorption of NH3 on the weakly acidic sites, but a desorption peak was produced at 277 °C, which was attributed to the desorption of the medium to strong acidic sites. Although the peak area when unloaded with Mn was larger than that when loaded with Mn, the peak area was mainly concentrated in the desorption peaks generated by adsorption on the weakly acidic sites, and the peak areas of the desorption peaks generated on the medium and strong acidic sites were small, indicating that the amount of acid was mainly concentrated on the weakly acidic sites, and the desorption peaks generated on the weakly acidic sites were unstable. The amount of acid in the medium to strong acidic sites and in the strong acidic sites increased after Mn loading, suggesting that the addition of Mn promoted the production of higher strength acidic sites. The peak area was greatest at 12% Mn loading, indicating the greatest amount of acid, which corresponds to the denitrification activity. The experimental study of NH3-TPD was carried out on Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F- CePO4 catalysts with different amounts of sulphuric acid after loading with the active substance Mn, as shown in Fig. 4(b). The peak area of the catalyst increased after acidification with sulphuric acid, with the largest peak area at a concentration of 0.6 mol/L, indicating that the relative number of desorbed species was greatest at this time. Desorption peaks were generated near 200 °C, at 300 °C and greater than 400 °C, attributed to weakly acidic sites on the catalyst surface, moderately strongly acidic sites and strongly acidic sites, respectively, with no decrease in the number of adsorption sites and an increase in peak area, indicating that the strongest adsorption capacity of NH3 was indicated at this time, corresponding to the denitrification activity. However, when the sulphuric acid amount was 1 mol/L, the peak area increased compared to that of unsulphated, but the number of acid sites became smaller, and there was only a more obvious desorption peak at less than 200 °C, indicating that the amount of adsorbed material on the surface of the catalyst was small, which reduced its denitrification activity, and although the peak area increased compared to that of unsulphated, the number of acid sites decreased significantly, making the adsorption capacity of NH3 weaker. 3.4 H2-TPR To investigate the effect of different Mn loadings on the redox properties of Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4, H2-TPR tests were carried out, as shown in Fig. 5 (a). The stronger redox properties increase the rate of conversion of NO to NO2 and the reactivity of the reaction. It can be seen from the graph that after loading Mn, a reduction peak appears at 530∼580 °C, corresponding to the reduction of Mn3+→Mn2+ [12] The reduction peak at 731 °C corresponds to the reduction of the bulk phase Ce4+ to Ce3+ on the catalyst surface, and the peak here shifts towards the lower temperature section after loading with Mn, indicating that Mn promotes the reduction of the bulk phase Ce4+ to Ce3+ on the catalyst surface, resulting in a higher reduction, corresponding to the denitrification activity. The overall peak area was greatest at 12%Mn loading, indicating the strongest reduction capacity, which corresponds to the trend in catalyst activity. After loading with the active substance Mn, the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalysts with different amounts of sulphuric acid were tested for H2-TPR, as shown in Fig. 5(b). It can be seen from the graph that a reduction peak appears at 731 °C, corresponding to the reduction of the bulk phase Ce4+ to Ce3+ on the catalyst surface. At 0.6 mol/L sulphuric acid, the position of the secondary reduction peak remains the same, but the peak area increases, and at 1 mol/L sulphuric acid, the secondary reduction peak is shifted towards the low-temperature section, but the peak area is significantly reduced. A reduction peak at 530∼580 °C corresponds to the reduction of Mn3+→Mn2+ [12]. The peak here is significantly enhanced at 0.6 mol/L and disappears again at 1 mol/L, indicating that the right amount of sulphuric acid plays a decisive role in the reduction of Mn3+→Mn2+. The graph also shows the order of peak areas: 0.6 mol H2SO4 > 0 mol H2SO4 > 1 mol H2SO4, which corresponds to the reduction capacity of the catalyst and corresponds to the trend in catalyst activity. 3.5 XPS The catalyst surface composition and chemical state have an important influence on the catalytic activity. To investigate the effect of Mn loading and sulphate acidification and sulphuric acid amount on the elemental valence of the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst, XPS tests were carried out on samples for Ce, Mn, P, S and O elements. As shown in Fig. 6 , the XPS spectrum of Ce 3d shows that there are eight characteristic peaks in the Ce 3d spectrum. amongst them, u(900.8 eV), u"(907.5 eV), u"'(916.5 eV), v(882.3 eV), v"(888.9 eV), v"'(898.4 eV) belong to Ce4+, u'(903.8 eV), the characteristic peak of v'(884.7 eV) belongs to Ce3+ [13,14] From the XPS spectrum of Ce 3d in Fig. 6(a), it can be seen that the peaks attributed to Ce3+ and Ce4+ are shifted to higher energy levels after loading Mn, indicating that the electron cloud of Cen+ species changes after loading Mn, driven by the induction effect of Mnn+ species. As shown in Table 1 , the order of Ce3+/(Ce4++Ce3+) ratio was Mn(12%)>Mn(10%)>Mn(15%)>Mn(5%), which corresponded to the denitrification activity, indicating that the Mn loading had a greater effect on the conversion ability of Ce4+ to Ce3+. The proportion of Ce3+ was the largest when the Mn loading was 12%, and Ce3+ moved the largest distance toward the higher energy level, indicating that Ce3+ was one of the main factors affecting the denitrification activity. From the XPS spectrum of Ce 3d in Fig. 6(b), it can be seen that all the characteristic peaks attributed to Cen+ are shifted towards the high binding energy after sulfuric acidification, implying that the Cen+ electron cloud is changed, which may be driven by the induced effect of sulfuric acid leading to the change of the electron cloud. It can be seen from Table 2 that the ratio of Ce3+/(Ce4++Ce3+) increased after sulfuric acid acidification, and the largest ratio was found at 0.6 mol/L. The available literature shows that the higher the ratio of Ce3+/(Ce4++Ce3+), the higher the catalyst has unsaturated chemical energy band and more oxygen vacancies, which will promote the NH3 adsorption of the reactant substances, and Ce3+ can promote the oxidation of NO to NO2, thus improving the activity of the catalyst [15–17]. It is shown that sulfuric acid acidification can promote the conversion of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and the improvement of denitrification activity of the catalyst. The XPS spectra of Mn 2p with different Mn loadings are shown in Fig. 7 (a). The characteristic peaks with binding energies in the range of 641.1 eV belong to Mn2+, 642.1 eV to Mn3+, and 644.1 eV to Mn4+ [18]. The characteristic peaks of Mnn+ are all shifted toward higher binding energies compared to the binding energies of the standard characteristic peaks, indicating that the Mn species interacted with the carrier as the active component, with the largest shift distance at 12% Mn loading and the most pronounced shift for Mn4+, indicating that the interaction between Mn4+ and the carrier had a significant effect on denitrification activity. It has been shown that Mn4+ species are more active than other Mn species and that increased levels of Mn4+ species can facilitate the oxidation of species in the NH3-SCR reaction [19–23]. It has also been suggested that the larger the ratio of (Mn3++Mn4+)/(Mn4++Mn3++Mn2+), the better the redox cycle of the manganese oxide can be achieved [24–26]. As can be seen from Table 1, the ratio of Mn3+ and (Mn3++Mn4+) for the catalyst with the best denitrification efficiency is not the greatest, indicating that the element Mn is not at its optimum at this time and that its superior denitrification performance is derived from the other elements and inter-element interactions. The XPS spectra of Mn 2p acidified with different amounts of H2SO4 are shown in Fig. 7(b). In agreement with the results shown in Fig. 7(a), the characteristic peaks of Mnn+ were all shifted toward the high binding energy, indicating that Mnn+ interacts with other substances as the active component. As can be seen from Table 2, the ratio of catalyst (Mn3++Mn4+)/(Mn4++Mn3++Mn2+) was greatest for a sulphuric acid amount of 0.6 mol/L, which corresponds to the H2-TPR results. The XPS spectra of P 2p are shown in Fig. 8 (a). 134.3 eV characteristic peaks are attributed to PO3 − and 133.2 eV characteristic peaks are attributed to PO4 3− [27,28]. It can be seen from Table 1 that the ratio of PO4 3−/(PO4 3−+PO3 −) on the catalyst surface shows a trend of increasing and then decreasing with the increase of Mn loading. The maximum ratio of PO4 3−/(PO4 3−+PO3 −) was observed at 12% of Mn loading, which indicates that the P element on the catalyst surface is mainly in the form of PO4 3− at this time. It has been shown that PO3 − hinders the reduction cycle of Ce4+ [29], which corresponds to the H2-TPR results. The XPS spectra of different sulfate acidified P 2p are shown in Fig. 8(b). As can be seen from Table 2, the ratio of PO4 3−/(PO4 3−+PO3 −) is maximum when the amount of H2SO4 is 0.6 mol/L, and the ratio of PO4 3−/(PO4 3−+PO3 −) decreases when the amount of H2SO4 increases to 1 mol/L, indicating that the PO3 − content on the surface of the catalyst sample is too large at this time, which will hinder the reduction cycle of Ce4+, which corresponds to the H2-TPR results corresponding to the H2-TPR results. The XPS spectra of S 2p both consist of two peaks, as shown in Fig. 9(a). 169.4 eV is attributed to S 2p1/2 photoelectron emission and 168.3 eV to S 2p3/2 photoelectron emission, both of which are signs of the presence of S6+ [30,31]. As can be seen from the figure, the overall shift of the binding energy of S 2p toward higher binding energy after loading Mn indicates that Mn interacts with the sulfate ion and possibly generates the new substance MnSO4, which is consistent with the results of XRD analysis. The XPS spectra of S 2p after sulfate acidification are shown in Fig. 9(b). Both peaks attributed to S6+ appeared in the figure, indicating the formation of sulfate species after sulfuric acidification. The peak at the sulfuric acid amount of 1 mol/L is shifted to lower binding energy compared to that at 0.6 mol/L, indicating that sulfuric acidification can cause the interaction between Fe and Ce species and sulfate species. The peak area attributed to the S 2p3/2 photoelectron emission occurring at the binding energy of 168.3 eV was significantly larger at 0.6 mol/L than at 1 mol/L sulfuric acid, confirming that the species attributed to this peak may promote some of the catalyst activity. The O 1 s XPS spectra all consisted of three peaks, and the O 1 s XPS spectra for different Mn loadings are shown in Fig. 10 (a). The characteristic peak at 533∼534 eV belongs to the characteristic peak of molecular adsorbed oxygen, marked as O', and the oxygen species near 531.3∼531.9 eV belongs to the characteristic peak produced by atomic adsorption of oxygen, marked as O'', near 529.3∼530.0 eV Oxygen species appearing are assigned to characteristic peaks of lattice oxygen species, marked as O'''. As can be seen from the graphs, the catalysts loaded with Mn have both molecularly and atomically adsorbed oxygen species, as well as lattice oxygen species, and the atomically adsorbed oxygen species are predominant. From Table 1, it can be seen that the proportion of O'' is the largest at 10% of Mn, but the denitrification performance is not optimal, probably because its shift towards higher binding energy found at too large a distance, which inhibits part of the denitrification activity. The Mn loading was 12% and the O'' ratio was not the highest, but the denitrification activity was the best, indicating that the interaction between elements on the catalyst surface had a significant effect on the denitrification performance. The XPS spectra of O 1 s acidified with different amounts of H2SO4 are shown in Fig. 10(b). As can be seen from the graph, the large increase in oxygen adsorbed on the catalyst surface after sulphation is a result of the action of sulphuric acid. With the addition of sulphuric acid, the proportion of surface adsorbed oxygen O'' rises from 41.97% to 58.76% and then decreases to 52.26%, indicating that the amount of sulphuric acid is not the larger the better, too much sulphuric acid will reduce the surface adsorbed oxygen content and inhibit the NH3-SCR reaction, as opposed to denitrification activity. 3.6 Catalytic NH3-SCR performances To test the denitration catalytic performance of Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst with different Mn loads (Loads: 0%, 5%, 8%, 10%, 12%, 15%). As shown in Fig. 11 (a), the denitration performance of the catalyzer tends to increase first and then decrease with the increase of Mn load. At 12%, the denitrification rate is the highest. In the range of 200 °C to 400 °C, the denitration rate is greater than 80%, maintained at a high level, 250 °C reached 92%. When the loading amount is 5%, the denitration efficiency is less than that of unloaded Mn. The denitrification efficiency when the loading amount is 8% is significantly higher than that when no Mn is loaded, and the denitration efficiency increases significantly from 200 °C. When the loading amount is 8%, 10%, and 12%, the denitration efficiency changes in a similar way, and it decreases significantly at 15%. This may be because the high concentration of active substances is easier to crystallize and sinter, which affects the denitration activity [32]. It shows that the optimal loading of Mn is 12%, the denitration activity has been improved from the low temperature of 150 °C, and the temperature window has become wider. At 200∼400 °C, the denitrification rate was always above 80%, and at 250 °C, the denitration activity reached a maximum of 92.6%. It can be seen from the small graph in Fig. 11(a) that when the transition metal Mn is loaded, the N2 selectivity increases only when the loading amount is 5%, and the N2 selectivity decreases when the loading amount exceeds 8%. The reason for this phenomenon may be that the MnO2 species in the catalyst has a strong oxidizing ability, which increases the production of by-product N2O in the NH3-SCR reaction, resulting in a decrease in the N2 selectivity of the catalyst [33,34]. After loading Mn, the denitration catalytic performance of Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalysts with different amounts of sulfuric acid (the amount of sulfuric acid was 0 mol/L, 0.6 mol/L, and 1 mol/L, respectively) was tested, in Fig. 2(b) shown. It can be found that the denitration activity of the catalyst increases first and then decreases when the carrier is not sulfated, reaching a maximum of 81.4% at 300 °C, and the activity decreases significantly after 300 °C. When the amount of sulfuric acid is 0.6 mol/L, the denitration activity of the catalyst in each temperature section is improved compared with that of the non-sulfated catalyst. The highest activity reaches 92.6%, and the temperature window becomes wider. However, when the amount of sulfuric acid increased to 1 mol/L, the denitration activity decreased significantly. The denitration activity below 300 °C was lower than that of the unsulfated one, and the denitration activity above 350 °C was higher than that of the unsulfated one. The overall denitration activity was lower than that of the catalyst when the amount of sulfuric acid was 0.6 mol/L, indicating that the appropriate amount of sulfuric acid had a great influence on the activity of the catalyst. It can be seen from the small graph in Fig. 11(b) that the N2 selectivity increases significantly after sulfuric acid acidification. With the increase of the sulfuric acid amount, the N2 selectivity increases, indicating that sulfuric acid acidification has an important influence on the N2 selectivity. 3.7 In situ drifts From the activity test results, it can be seen that the 12% loaded Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst exhibited a NOx conversion of 80% over a wide temperature range of 200 °C∼400 °C, with the best at 250 °C and a NOx conversion of 92%. The N2 selectivity of the catalyst was reduced compared to the unloaded version but remained between 70% and 80%. In this section, the mechanism of NH3-SCR reaction with Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst is investigated and discussed. 3.7.1 Variation of NH3 and NO+O2 adsorption on the catalyst with time Fig. 12 (a) shows the infrared spectrum of NH3 adsorption with time for the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst obtained after loading with Mn at 250 °C. As can be seen from the graph, when NH3 was passed through for 5 min, three distinct IR absorption peaks appeared on the catalyst surface at 1774 cm−1, 1639 cm−1 and 1421 cm−1. The absorption peak at 1774 cm−1 is attributed to an absorption peak due to weakly adsorbed or gaseous NH3 [35], and the absorption peak at 1639 cm−1 is attributed to the dehydrogenation product -NH2 species of the Lewis acid centre adsorbed NH3 species. The absorption peak at 1421 cm−1 belongs to the deformation vibration of the NH bond in the Brønsted acid centre adsorbed NH4 + species. With increasing passage time, at 10 min, only the absorption peak of -NH2 species was present on the catalyst surface, thus indicating a faster activation rate of NH3 adsorption at the Lewis acidic site on the catalyst surface, which facilitates the reaction. From 20 to 30 min, two new absorption peaks appeared on the surface of the catalyst at 1248 cm−1 and 1722 cm−1, which were respectively attributed to the NH3 species adsorbed by the Lewis acid centre and the dehydrogenation product NH3 + species of the Brønsted acid centre adsorbed NH4 + species [36]. With the purging of N2, the absorption peaks at 1421 cm−1 for NH4 + species belonging to the Brønsted acid centre and at 1248 cm−1 for NH3 species belonging to the Lewis acid centre weakened, while the absorption peak at 1722 cm−1 disappeared, indicating their susceptibility to adsorption. However, NH3 species belonging to the Lewis acid centre adsorbed on the catalyst surface appeared at 1615 cm−1, indicating that the adsorption-desorption process of NH3 on the Lewis acidic site was not affected by N2. These results show that the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst is rich in acidic sites on the catalyst surface at 250 °C and that all of them can participate in the reaction, but it is obvious that the Lewis acidic site has a faster activation rate of NH3(g) adsorption and is less likely to be interfered by the purging of the equilibrium gas, so the Lewis acidic site is the main active site on the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst surface. Fig. 12(b) shows the IR spectrum of the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst for NO+O2 adsorption at 250 °C with time. IR absorption peaks can be found on the catalyst surface at 1774 cm−1, 1418 cm−1 and 1247 cm−1 when NO+O2 is passed through for 5 min. Where the absorption peak at 1774 cm−1 belongs to the stretching vibration of the N=O bond. The absorption peak at 1418 cm−1 belongs to the monodentate nitrite species [35]. The absorption peak at 1247 cm−1 belongs to a bridging nitrate species. The Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst showed the presence of monodentate nitrite species on the surface, which are nitrate species with high reactivity and contribute to lower reaction temperatures, which is consistent with the activity test results. This could likewise indicate that Mn3+ readily bonds with monodentate nitrite species to form ON-O-Mn3+ species involved in the L-H mechanistic reaction process. With increasing passage time, at 20 min the monodentate nitrite species were further oxidised to monodentate nitrate species(1464 cm−1) and the bidentate nitrate species (1743 cm−1) were also present in a more stable state. In contrast, the absorption peak of the bridged nitrate species was enhanced at 20 min but was further oxidised to the bidentate nitrate species(1345 cm−1) with increasing time. After a 30 min N2 purge it was found that the bidentate nitrate species remained stable, while the bidentate nitrate species at 1345 cm−1 was also reduced to a monodentate nitrate species (1284 cm−1), which also illustrates the excellent redox ability of Mnn+. The above results indicate that the main NO adsorption products on the surface of the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst were monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate species. 3.7.2 Variation of NH3 and NO+O2 adsorption on the catalyst with temperature Fig. 13 (a) shows the spectrum of the change in thermal stability of NH3 adsorbed species over the interval 50 °C to 400 °C for the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst. Firstly, it can be observed that at low temperatures between 50 °C and 150 °C, infrared absorption peaks appear on the catalyst surface at 1725 cm−1, 1641 cm−1, 1422 cm−1 and 1241 cm−1. The peak at 1725 cm−1 belongs to the NH3 + species, a dehydrogenation product of NH4 + adsorbed on the Brønsted acid centre on the catalyst surface, and the peak at 1641 cm−1 belongs to the -NH2 species, a dehydrogenation product of NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid centre, indicating that the NH4 +/NH3 species adsorbed on the acidic sites are more reactive at low temperatures. The absorption peak at 1422 cm−1 belongs to the deformation vibration of the NH bond in NH4 + adsorbed at the Brønsted acid centre on the catalyst surface, and the absorption peak at 1241 cm−1 belongs to the NH3 species adsorbed at the Lewis acid centre on the catalyst surface. As the temperature increases, the NH3(a) species at 1241 cm−1 undergoes dehydrogenation to form the -NH2 species and the absorption peak is shifted to 1320 cm−1. NH4 + species belonging to the Brønsted acid centre adsorbed on the catalyst surface appeared in the interval 200 °C to 300 °C (1688 cm−1). When the temperature was increased to 350 °C∼400 °C, new IR absorption peaks appeared on the catalyst surface at 1773 cm−1 and 1541 cm−1. The adsorption peaks due to weakly adsorbed or gaseous NH3, and the Brønsted acid-centred adsorption of NH4 + species, respectively. Combined with the activity test results, it can be seen that the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst exhibited good catalytic activity from the low to high temperature section, indicating that the dehydrogenation product -NH2 species in the Lewis acidic site and the Brønsted acidic site on the catalyst surface are the main active species and acid active site on the catalyst surface. Fig. 13(b) shows the spectrum of thermal stability changes of NO+O2 adsorbed species for the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst in the interval from 50 °C to 400 °C. In the low temperature band from 50 °C to 150 °C, infrared absorption peaks appeared on the catalyst surface at 1699 cm−1, 1578 cm−1, 1513 cm−1 and 1350 cm−1. The absorption peaks at 1578 cm−1 and 1350 cm−1 both belong to the bidentate nitrate species, the peak at 1699 cm−1 belongs to the bidentate nitrite species and the absorption peak at 1513 cm−1 belongs to the monodentate nitrate species. This suggests that the catalytic activity is poorer at low temperatures as the nitrate species on the catalyst surface are more stable and thus less conducive to reacting with the adsorbed NH3 species. With the increase in temperature, a weakening of the absorption peaks of the bidentate nitrate species on the catalyst surface can be observed (1350 cm−1, 1578 cm−1), indicating that this part of the bidentate nitrate species undergoes reduction reactions and is followed by absorption peaks attributed to monodentate nitrate (1459 cm−1) and monodentate nitrite species (1418 cm−1), which are more reactive nitrate species that react more readily with NH3 species. Not only that, but the decomposition and reaction of bidentate nitrate also exposes certain active sites favourable for the activation of other reactive gases by adsorption. However, in the medium to high-temperature section (200 °C∼400 °C), the catalyst surface was still dominated by bidentate nitrate species, with absorption peaks located at 1638 cm−1 and 1544 cm−1. The absorption peaks appearing at 1758 cm−1 and 1522 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of the N=O bond and the monodentate nitrate species. Overall, the high-temperature section had fewer reactive nitrate species and was susceptible to pyrolysis and desorption by temperature, which combined with the results of the activity tests suggests that NO is less likely to be involved in the reaction in the form of nitrate species. 3.7.3 Reaction of NH3 and NO+O2 pre-adsorption Fig. 14 (a) shows the in situ IR spectrum of the reaction of NO+O2 on the surface of the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst with preadsorbed NH3 species at a temperature of 250 °C. The change in the IR spectrum was observed at a temperature of 250 °C. Firstly, after the adsorption of NH3 1 h, the catalyst showed three distinct IR absorption peaks at 1609 cm−1, 1421 cm−1 and 1260 cm−1. The absorption peaks at 1609 cm−1 and 1260 cm−1 belong to the NH3 species adsorbed by the Lewis acid centre. The absorption peak at 1471 cm−1 belongs to the deformation vibration of the NH bond in the NH4 + adsorbed at the Brønsted acid centre on the catalyst surface. It is suggested that the Lewis acidic sites are the main acidic sites on the surface of the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst, in agreement with the results in Fig. 12(a). When NO+O2 was introduced, the absorption peak of NH3 species belonging to the Lewis acid centre adsorbed at 1609 cm−1 disappeared rapidly, indicating a rapid reaction with the NO species, following the E-R mechanism. In contrast, the peak at 1260 cm−1 diminished, indicating that some of it also reacted with NO, while the incompletely reacted NH3(a) species also reacted completely after 10 min of NO+O2 passage. The absorption peak of NH4 + species adsorbed at the Brønsted acid centre is not affected but rather enhanced by the passage of NO+O2, implying that NO does not react with NH4 + species and that the enhanced absorption peak is probably due to the oxidation of NH3 species to produce nitrate species. The catalyst surface also showed bridged nitrate species (1686 cm−1, 1260 cm−1), and monodentate nitrate species (1512 cm−1) after the NO was passed through. Fig. 14(b) shows the in situ IR spectrum of the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst for the reaction of NH3 with pre-adsorbed NO+O2 species at 250 °C. When NO+O2 was introduced into the reaction cell system for 60 min, stable double-dentate nitrite species (1690 cm−1), single-dentate nitrate species (1373 cm−1) and even secondary nitrate species (1145 cm−1) appeared on the catalyst surface [35]. After cutting off NO+O2 followed by NH3, it can be found that the 1690 cm−1 bidentate nitrite species did not react, but formed a compound absorption peak with the adsorbed NH3 species at 2 min of NH3 introduction, which was still present in a more stable state at 5 min, and was gradually reduced to other nitrate products under the action of reducing gas as the time of NH3 introduction increased. In contrast, the monodentate nitrate species disappeared quickly with the passage of NH3, indicating the presence of an L-H reaction mechanism on the catalyst surface. Even the secondary nitrate species reacted with NH3 at a slow rate, with decomposition disappearing only at 10 min pass, suggesting that the monodentate nitrate species on the surface of the Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst was the main active reactive species. The adsorption of NH3 onto the catalyst surface also produced several adsorption products, with the absorption peaks at 1642 cm−1, 1622 cm−1, 1302 cm−1 and 1651 cm−1 all belonging to the NH3 dehydrogenation product -NH2 species adsorbed at the Lewis acid centre. The absorption peak at 1238 cm−1 belongs to the NH3 species adsorbed by the Lewis acid centre, while the absorption peak at 1460 cm−1 belongs to the NH4 + species adsorbed by the Brønsted acid centre on the catalyst surface. 3.8 Sulphur and water resistance testing Fig. 15 shows the experiment of sulfur and water resistance of Mn/SO4 2−- CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst. In the programmed ramp-up experiment, 500 ppm NH3, 500 ppm NO, 3% O2 and N2 equilibrium gas were first introduced at a certain temperature within the optimum temperature range of the catalyst, and after 30 min of reaction, 500 ppm SO2 and 5% H2O were introduced, and after 30 min of reaction, SO2 and H2O were cut off, and after 30 min of reaction, the temperature was ramped up for the next temperature point. In isothermal experiments, 500 ppm NH3, 500 ppm NO, 3% O2 and N2 equilibrium gas were firstly introduced at the optimum catalyst temperature and after 2 h of reaction, 500 ppm SO2 and 5% H2O were introduced and after 8 h of reaction, SO2 and H2O were cut off and the reaction continued for 2 h. From the experimental results, it is clear that the catalysts maintained excellent catalytic performance from 200 °C to 400 °C, and the best denitrification temperature was 250 °C (92.6%). The catalyst activity decreased by about 30% under low-temperature conditions, but the resistance to toxicity was relatively improved with the increase in temperature. After cutting off H2O+SO2, the catalytic activity was recovered in all cases. The experimental results at 250 °C showed that the catalytic activity continued to decrease by about 30% with increasing time, and the activity rebounded somewhat after cutting off the pass-through. It indicates that the poisoning on the catalyst surface is still mainly from the competing adsorption generated by SO2, H2O and NH3, NO, and most of the -OH cannot be removed at this temperature, which will affect the redox performance of the Mn-Ce system. However, due to the excellent redox properties of Mnn+, it was not affected by H2O and resulted in inactivation. 3.9 Mechanism analysis The catalyst surface reaction mechanism is shown in Fig. 16 : The equation for the reaction is as follows(M=Ce, Fe, Mn) (Δ=SO3 2−, PO4 3−): L-H Mechanism: NH3(g)+Δ→Δ-NH3(ad) Mn++O2→M( n + 1)++2O− Δ-NH3(ad)+O−→Δ-NH2+OH− NH3(g)+Δ-OH→Δ-NH4 ++O− Δ-NH4 ++O−→Δ-NH3 ++OH− Δ-NH3 ++-OH+O−→Δ-NH2+2-OH NO+O−→-NO2 2NO(g)+O2→2NO2(g) NO2(g)+O−→-NO3 Δ-NH2+-NO2→Δ-NH2-NO2 Δ-NH2-NO2+M( n + 1)+→N2+H2O+Δ+Mn++O − Δ-NH2+-NO3→Δ-NH2-NO3 Δ-NH2-NO3+M( n + 1)+→N2+H2O+Δ+Mn++2O− E-R Mechanism: NH3(g)+Δ→Δ-NH3(ad) Mn++O2→M( n + 1)++2O− Δ-NH3(ad)+O−→Δ-NH2+OH− NH3(g)+Δ-OH→Δ-NH4 ++O− 2NO(g)+O2→2NO2(g) Δ-NH2+NO(g)→Δ-NH2NO→N2+H2O+Δ Δ-NH4 ++NO2(g)→Δ-NH4NO2→Δ-NH2NO+H2O Δ-NH2NO→N2+H2O+Δ 4 Conclusion The Mn/SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalyst was prepared by the impregnation method, and the effects of different manganese nitrate content and sulphuric acid content on the catalyst activity were investigated respectively. The surface properties of the catalyst were analysed by a series of characterisations, and its NH3-SCR reaction path and reaction mechanism at the optimum denitrification temperature of 250 °C were explored, with the following main conclusions: (1) The best denitrification performance of the catalyst was achieved at 12% Mn loading and 0.6 mol/L sulphuric acid content, and the temperature window became wider, with denitrification consistently above 80% at 200∼400 °C and up to 92.6% denitrification activity at 250 °C. (2) Mn content and sulphuric acid content have a significant effect on denitrification performance, with suitable Mn and sulphuric acid content leading to greater Mn-Ce interactions and an increase in the amount of acid in the moderately strong acidic sites and strong acidic sites; The Mn oxides, MnSO4 and MnSO3 produced are well dispersed and provide more adsorption sites and active sites; The Mn atom replaces part of the Ce atom in the CeO2 lattice, increasing the mobility of the oxygen and thus improving the low-temperature activity of the catalyst; Promotes the conversion of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and the elevated proportion of oxygen adsorbed on the surface, accelerating the NH3-SCR reaction. (3) The Mn-loaded catalyst follows both the E-R and L-H mechanisms at medium to high temperatures (250 °C) and has a significantly different reaction path to that of the carrier following the L-H mechanism. Acidic sites are abundant on the catalyst surface, with Lewis acidic sites being the main active sites on the catalyst surface. The main NO adsorption products on the catalyst surface were monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrite species. The dehydrogenation product -NH2 species at the Lewis acidic site of the surface is the main active species on the catalyst surface. Monodont nitrate species are the main active nitrate species. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, NH3-SCR catalysts were prepared by impregnating transition metal Mn loaded on SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 and adding sulphuric acid to further improve the denitrification performance of the catalysts. The optimum performance of the catalysts was explored by varying the loading ratio of Mn and the concentration of sulphuric acid. XRD, Raman, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, XPS and In situ DRIFTS were used to characterise the changes in the surface properties of the catalyst after loading with Mn and to investigate the reaction mechanism. The results show that the denitrification performance of the catalyst was improved after the loading of Mn and sulphuric acid treatment, and the temperature window became wider, with the denitrification rate consistently remaining above 80% at 200∼400 °C and the denitrification activity reaching 92.6% at 250 °C. Suitable Mn and sulphuric acid content allow for greater Mn-Ce interactions, resulting in better dispersion of active substances such as Mn oxides, MnSO4 and MnSO3, which can provide more adsorption and active sites and increase the reaction rate. The Mn atoms replace some of the Ce atoms in the CeO2 lattice, increasing the mobility of oxygen and thus improving the low-temperature activity of the catalyst. In situ IR results show that the catalyst follows both the Eley-Rideal mechanism and the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism at 250 °C. The acidic sites on the surface are abundant and the Lewis acidic sites are the main active sites on the catalyst surface. Both mechanisms work together to facilitate the denitrification reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Study on NH3-SCR performance and mechanism of Mn supported SO4 2−-CeCO3F-CePO4 catalysts
